CB01B164114D4778B81C67A796391865.description:
Safety 
Students will be encouraged to: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., wear safety goggles when testing the cleavage or fracture of rocks; ensure the proper disposal of materials)

7987BC1925D24280989E5A63CDAC1D90.description:
Stewardship 
Students will be encouraged to: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., recognize that fossils are a part of public heritage and that they should not be defaced or removed from where they are found; consider the needs of other people and the precariousness of the environment when making decisions and taking action)

A3936EFB3EA44B3BAEDE6FE7895686A2.description:
Collaboration 
Students will be encouraged to: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., listen to the ideas and points of view of others; consider alternative ideas and interpretations suggested by members of the group)

FF4E46CBEA584AB3B6B503CD9EA366EC.description:
Scientific Inquiry 
Students will be encouraged to: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., critically evaluate inferences and conclusions, basing their arguments on facts rather than opinions; identify evidence to support ideas; take the time to accurately gather evidence and use instruments carefully)

48694998F9A847D6B851BCD10DCD28F0.description:
Mutual Respect 
Students will be encouraged to: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., appreciate the idea of “Mother Earth,” and recognize different forms of this idea developed by different cultures; recognize the role of legend and myth in conveying understandings about Earth; recognize that scientific ideas about Earth have developed over time)

FB7F6A03503347A5B5432DB306BD3710.description:
Interest in Science 
Students will be encouraged to: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., recognize potential careers related to Earth science fields; pursue interests in rocks, through museum visits, personal collections or recreational reading)

8817FE666FEC4A73ABF49815AEA03434.description: • evaluate individual and group processes used in planning, problem solving, decision making and completing a task (e.g., evaluate the relative success and scientific merits of an Earth science field trip organized and guided by themselves)

A3252F6278C243DDBFD174083B95E803.description: • work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., each group member is assigned a task to investigate a particular mineral, and the results are pooled in a common data table)

CDECBD19F623494CA0EB37EB11E172A3.description:
Communication and Teamwork 
Students will: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

E33B277562BE4CE4886D30489FBF7EA3.description: • identify new questions and problems that arise from what was learned (e.g., identify new questions that arise after learning about plate tectonics)

63062929AF37417B9501F1EDBB6104E2.description: • identify and suggest explanations for discrepancies in data (e.g., suggest explanations for an igneous rock being found in a sedimentary formation)

F6977DEA36554FF08F15E54D98B7E6D9.description:
• predict the value of a variable, by interpolating or extrapolating from data (e.g., determine, in a
stream table study, the quantity of sediment carried over a half-hour period, then extrapolate the
amount that would be carried if the time were extended to a day, month, year or millennium)

ECAB94C9F1F441B0B3D915779C38C824.description:
• interpret patterns and trends in data, and infer and explain relationships among the variables (e.g.,
interpret example graphs of seismic data, and explain the lag time between data received at
different locations)

7BC439CA24E74E099FC90056D776422B.description:
• use or construct a classification key (e.g., apply a classification key to identify a group of rocks
from a local gravel yard)

6A502B3A6BA042EEAB929512731DFE14.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting 
Students will: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

AEB9799EF88F4D88BE5004D12778E17F.description:
• organize data, using a format that is appropriate to the task or experiment (e.g., use diagrams to
show the shape and thickness of different layers in a rock outcrop)

EEC9D846DAA249F088F2AF249618B9E6.description:
• select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of
the same source (e.g., demonstrate proficiency in uploading and downloading text, image, audio
and video files)

6A35BFD7548640689F20B3B27586D421.description:
• research information relevant to a given question (e.g., research information regarding the effect
of acid rain on the rate of rock weathering)

D58960F9FBD8426BA9CCF8AF1B7FF1D6.description: • estimate measurements (e.g., estimate the thickness of sedimentary layers)

F679B53356FA4B728641AF6DA56546FB.description: • carry out procedures, controlling the major variables

9C6AFCDABADB40BB86F0AD782A580E6A.description:
Performing and Recording 
Students will: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

60BB791DF016490E8AACB69336CBEE0F.description: • formulate operational definitions of major variables and other aspects of their investigations (e.g., define hardness by reference to a set of mineral samples, or by reference to the Mohs’ scale of hardness)

59DBA3CE114944459CC9D45F0117CBA1.description: • state a prediction and a hypothesis based on background information or an observed pattern of events (e.g., predict where an outcrop of a given rock will appear, based on observations at nearby sites)

CC6BF09D9E154DD7B0F1AE96538FD5F1.description: • define and delimit questions to facilitate investigation (e.g., ask a question about a sample group of rocks from a specific region, or about a specific type of rock or rock formation)

A599907171BE485CAC2DEA8AF001BFC4.description: • identify questions to investigate (e.g., How are rocks formed?)

C6AC47D0923949F7B93242752F304944.description:
Initiating and Planning 
Students will: Ask questions about the relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

A810B3A55FED433A8FB51F0B59711A60.description: • identify uncertainties in interpreting individual items of fossil evidence; and explain the role of accumulated evidence in developing accepted scientific ideas, theories and explanations

EDF8511BF71741619D2C6B2726A9479D.description: • describe patterns in the appearance of different life forms, as indicated by the fossil record (e.g., construct and interpret a geological time scale; and describe, in general terms, the evidence that has led to its development)

D4D73AA5CF1C4C24840A84A277BF2681.description: • explain and apply methods used to interpret fossils (e.g., identify techniques used for fossil reconstruction, based on knowledge of current living things and findings of related fossils; identify examples of petrified wood and bone)

F715A9149C9E4AEF864C7B480E83166C.description:
• describe the nature of different kinds of fossils, and identify hypotheses about their formation
(e.g., identify the kinds of rocks where fossils are likely to be found; identify the portions of living
things most likely to be preserved; identify possible means of preservation, including
replacement of one material by another and formation of molds and casts)

44EB698F441F4A128A4FD5FB4867A782.description: 4. Describe, interpret and evaluate evidence from the fossil record

09AF039F4B3F47409411E115658DD88E.description: • identify and interpret examples of gradual/incremental change, and predict the results of those changes over extended periods of time (e.g., identify evidence of erosion, and predict the effect of erosional change over a year, century and millennium; project the effect of a given rate of continental drift over a period of one million years)

88C8835D82A74595B87F1E93381091DC.description: • describe evidence for crustal movement, and identify and interpret patterns in these movements (e.g., identify evidence of earthquakes and volcanic action along the Pacific Rim; identify evidence of the movement of the Pacific plate relative to the North American plate)

57676ADD38A24107BD92759CF3CE24D5.description: • interpret the structure and development of fold and fault mountains

5E3372372F3340FD9805ACECED1A1B9E.description: • investigate and interpret patterns in the structure and distribution of mountain formations (e.g., describe and interpret mountain formations of the North American cordillera)

4BAE3829D7A94BC9B7B5AFEBB30A3F29.description: 3. Investigate and interpret evidence of major changes in landforms and the rock layers that underlie them

2BB481C17C55473CA9D2F2C269F515A0.description: • investigate and interpret examples of weathering, erosion and sedimentation

B6174E1886D24734966EA33B8D994EB8.description: • describe local rocks and sediments, and interpret ways they may have formed

75913D5A0FB2497493FCA9723D8C8CC2.description: • describe characteristics of the three main classes of rocks—igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic—and describe evidence of their formation (e.g., describe evidence of igneous rock formation, based on the study of rocks found in and around volcanoes; describe the role of fossil evidence in interpreting sedimentary rock)

9CA9BA3184FE4DCDA604FEAB72A812AD.description: 2. Identify evidence for the rock cycle, and use the rock cycle concept to interpret and explain the characteristics of particular rocks

B350BDC824FE422D91A83D596DC9523D.description: • explain the need for common terminology and conventions in describing rocks and minerals, and apply suitable terms and conventions in describing sample materials (e.g., use common terms in describing the lustre, transparency, cleavage and fracture of rocks and minerals; apply the Mohs’ scale in describing mineral hardness)

829AD99408E0436AA2CCD92A21FCC3E9.description: • identify and explain the purpose of different tools and techniques used in the study of Earth (e.g., describe and explain the use of seismographs and coring drills, as well as tools and techniques for the close examination of rocks; describe methods used in oil and gas exploration)

19222F28E279446AA08D3FD9BCD26E9F.description: • interpret models that show a layered structure for Earth’s interior; and describe, in general terms, evidence for such models

38798DA6960C4E84B03492FDC5E7C704.description: • interpret examples of variation in the design of structures that share a common function, and evaluate the effectiveness of the designs (e.g., compare and evaluate different forms of roofed structures, or different designs for communication towers)

19F84A4861CD42C09D347BB4FC9CAE43.description: • investigate and interpret evidence that Earth’s surface undergoes both gradual and sudden change (e.g., recognize earthquakes, volcanoes and landslides as examples of sudden change; recognize glacial erosion and river erosion as examples of gradual/incremental change)

2E8C4C98ED61428D85EC28932F09E140.description: 1. Describe and demonstrate methods used in the scientific study of Earth and in observing and interpreting its component materials

5E68F3F5016D49A28B0A67B29F5C1999.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society

881A09FA6C984838AF4C0173BC4CF057.description:
Safety 
Students will be encouraged to: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., readily alter a procedure to ensure the safety of members of the group; carefully manipulate materials, using skills learned in class or elsewhere; listen attentively to safety procedures given by the teacher)

AC5F3AEB11E14E2D8A54C59C3A14A78A.description:
Stewardship 
Students will be encouraged to: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., consider the cause-and-effect relationships of personal actions and decisions)

877438B70BF941799CFAFA3F3A23C5A4.description:
Collaboration 
Students will be encouraged to: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., accept various roles within a group, including that of leadership; remain interested and involved in decision making that requires full-group participation; understand that they may disagree with others but still work in a collaborative manner)

0EF6D3ECCA03476198C9C7B970D5581D.description:
Scientific Inquiry 
Students will be encouraged to: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., report the limitations of their designs; continue working on a problem or research project until the best possible solutions or answers are uncovered)

89984F97E43D414E9164ADFBB09DF310.description:
Mutual Respect 
Students will be encouraged to: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., recognize that a variety of structural forms have emerged fromd ifferent cultures at different times in history)

ECD59619B48449989AA4046DFA99ECD7.description:
Interest in Science 
Students will be encouraged to: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., apply knowledge of structures in interpreting a variety of structures within their home community; ask questions about techniques and materials used, and show an interest in construction and engineering)

B3E470A229A640BAA77C8C722C64711D.description: • work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan, and troubleshoot problems as they arise

AFCB4A92F11647979C1746E988B1ED8D.description: • communicate questions, ideas, intentions, plans and results, using lists, notes in point form, sentences, data tables, graphs, drawings, oral language and other means (e.g., produce a work plan, in cooperation with other team members, that identifies criteria for selecting materials and evaluating designs)

3DE59AFC5733453E8D2FB0911AA3E379.description:
Communication and Teamwork 
Students will: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

6C8F43331BBB4340A40F66DBEC3B172D.description: • identify and correct practical problems in the way a prototype or constructed device functions

C2C1364FAE724240B608749BD03A67A1.description: • evaluate designs and prototypes in terms of function, reliability, safety, efficiency, use of materials and impact on the environment

D99274C9A66A4BFFA706F7044EA49A15.description: • test the design of a constructed device or system (e.g., test and evaluate a prototype design of a foundation for a model building to be constructed on sand)

6E3C0CB0A53D453692A0F2F333BA029D.description: • identify and evaluate potential applications of findings (e.g., identify possible applications of materials for which they have studied the properties)

6B3D88BD2E5945CD82AFF4689938C5ED.description: • compile and display data, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, bar graphs, line graphs and scatterplots (e.g., plot a graph, showing the deflection of different materials tested under load)

F1321643A8264F87A6B50EFC8D917AC0.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting 
Students will: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

D07D105AE8DA4746B05062835C3D9BC2.description: • use tools and apparatus safely (e.g., select appropriate tools, and safely apply methods for joining materials; use saws and other cutting tools safely)

B582D6A7305F4DE99A83B446EB0DB9D3.description: • carry out procedures, controlling the major variables (e.g., ensure that tests to determine the effect of any one variable are based on changes to that variable only)

CC1EF203E2DD4CA2B3900F872ED51138.description: • organize data, using a format that is appropriate to the task or experiment (e.g., use a database or spreadsheet for recording the deformation of components under different loads)

4FFAF68E50DE4E4DA3C9A04F3DDBB59C.description: • research information relevant to a given problem

D684CDBC3D0742288556C405BAA2B253.description:
Performing and Recording 
Students will: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

D230D8A39DE8475BB1FB0372BD4D122F.description: • formulate operational definitions of major variables and other aspects of their investigations (e.g., define flexibility of a component as the amount of deformation for a given load)

2556D593233B411C936680D9EC2C3995.description: • select appropriate methods and tools for collecting data to solve problems (e.g., use or develop an appropriate method for determining if the mass of a structure is well distributed over its foundation)

44EE58A802544E48986B6CCBAB65D58B.description: • propose alternative solutions to a practical problem, select one, and develop a plan (e.g., propose an approach to increasing the stability of a structure)

1D1115F01FD24F9EAA2C99DF3FFDBF59.description: • identify practical problems (e.g., identify a problem related to the stability of a structure)

D411970B17FE49D6B45AD7DFC8F12AF6.description:
Initiating and Planning 
Students will: Ask questions about the relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

ADF6466F7D9445DD95A938619293B680.description: • analyze and evaluate a technological design or process on the basis of identified criteria, such as costs, benefits, safety and potential impact on the environment

2F98392C116D429E8C1021EBED8DC2FB.description: • identify environmental factors that may affect the stability and safety of a structure, and describe how these factors are taken into account (e.g., recognize that snow load, wind load and soil characteristics need to be taken into account in building designs; describe example design adaptations used in earthquake-prone regions)

AF3477D9BDE7454F8014C6F016BBDEBD.description: • demonstrate and describe methods to increase the strength of materials through changes in design (e.g., corrugation of surfaces, lamination of adjacent members, changing the shape of components, changing the method of fastening)

7C0D738BB2EA4CAE9794B5A87E217523.description: 4. Demonstrate and describe processes used in developing, evaluating and improving structures that will meet human needs with a margin of safety

99121C65D4EF48B2A187E0C5A55E289D.description: • investigate and describe the role of different materials found in plant and animal structures (e.g., recognize the role of bone, cartilage and ligaments in vertebrate animals, and the role of different layers of materials in plants

7E678773028A4532848B0C0DC000A580.description: • compare structural properties of different materials, including natural materials and synthetics

880D109818C14E5DA3E482BCCB51418D.description: • identify points in a structure where flexible or fixed joints are required, and evaluate the appropriateness of different types of joints for the particular application (e.g., fixed jointing by welding, gluing or nailing; hinged jointing by use of pins or flexible materials)

07DBF23296244470B6351636B8E8A55F.description: • devise and use methods of testing the strength and flexibility of materials used in a structure (e.g., measure deformation under load)

05157F1413DA4BADB02172AD50B7517D.description: 3. Investigate and analyze the properties of materials used in structures

DDCE0A0557EB47F486243B16BBA189A3.description: • infer how the stability of a model structure will be affected by changes in the distribution of mass within the structure and by changes in the design of its foundation (e.g., infer how the stability of a structure will be affected by increasing the width of its foundation)

37C63CC95A524E01BB6ECDD9F9B380F2.description: • analyze a design, and identify properties of materials that are important to individual parts of the structure (e.g., recognize that cables can be used as a component of structures where only tensile forces are involved; recognize that beams are subject to tension on one side and compression on the other; recognize that flexibility is important in some structures)

0C98E75E20094E5C8338444B26BCF744.description: • identify tension, compression, shearing and bending forces within a structure; and describe how these forces can cause the structure to fail (e.g., identify tensile forces that cause lengthening and possible snapping of a member; identify bending forces that could lead to breakage)

C5E55BB8B42B4AF1ADED3F14AE3BD105.description: • identify examples of frictional forces and their use in structures (e.g., friction of a nail driven into wood, friction of pilings or footings in soil, friction of stone laid on stone)

6B4FD9863EAA40658BC3DFB88D9CA999.description: • recognize and use units of force and mass, and identify and measure forces and loads

B16C9EE94F7648A6B0E345E1134C8308.description: 2. Investigate and analyze forces within structures, and forces applied to them

5D3615C9E873437C8B3EEFF662239016.description: • identify points of failure and modes of failure in natural and built structures (e.g., potential failure of a tree under snow load, potential failure of an overloaded bridge)

03204BBF09BC41DFA17BF7E89F796574.description: • describe and interpret natural structures, including the structure of living things and structures created by animals (e.g., skeletons, exoskeletons, trees, birds’ nests)

5C510F1DB9ED49DCACE71CC6C6AC7CAF.description: • describe and compare example structures developed by different cultures and at different times; and interpret differences in functions, materials and aesthetics (e.g., describe traditional designs of indigenous people and peoples of other cultures; compare classical and current designs; investigate the role of symmetry in design)

FE07DB231F254C219612FD6A301CB602.description: • interpret examples of variation in the design of structures that share a common function, and evaluate the effectiveness of the designs (e.g., compare and evaluate different forms of roofed structures, or different designs for communication towers)

830C4A624839445BA22686777E5A2C08.description: • recognize and classify structural forms and materials used in construction (e.g., identify examples of frame structures, such as goal posts and girder bridges, examples of shell structures, such as canoes and car roofs, and examples of frame-and-shell structures, such as houses and apartment buildings)

87B44E63F98A4B979DD7474164B55030.description: 1. Describe and interpret different types of structures encountered in everyday objects, buildings, plants and animals; and identify materials from which they are made

4B24C666E40F4BE6821C1358B0EA448F.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society

3A14D8B8924545A1A41791A76A3526FC.description:
Safety 
Students will be encouraged to: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., demonstrate concern for self and others in planning and carrying out experimental activities involving the heating of materials; select safe methods for collecting evidence and solving problems)

492C53E61B1A4006A2498D4E870590CE.description:
Stewardship 
Students will be encouraged to: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., recognize the distinction between renewable and nonrenewable resources and the implications this has for responsible action; objectively identify potential conflicts between responding to human wants and needs and protecting the environment)

E3B9FC7DED7C4ABAAC791B9E26311FD8.description:
Collaboration 
Students will be encouraged to: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., choose a variety of strategies, such as active listening, paraphrasing and questioning, in order to understand other points of view; seek consensus before making decisions)

9C1644569B7245528FCB7D2459725525.description:
Scientific Inquiry 
Students will be encouraged to: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems andissues (e.g., view a situation from different perspectives; propose options and compare them when making decisions or taking action)

87CE7BA4A8BD4DA4AD62175D95D13701.description:
Mutual Respect 
Students will be encouraged to: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., appreciate Aboriginal home designs of the past and present that use locally-available materials; recognize that science and technology develop in response to global concerns, as well as to local needs; consider more than one factor or perspective when making decisions on STS issues)

FB01207627BB48ACBFF82C8BE1513842.description:
Interest in Science 
Students will be encouraged to: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., apply ideas learned in asking and answering questions about everyday phenomena related to heat; show interest in a broad scope of science-related fields in which heat plays a significant role)

A78E3E7D4ED34AB78A753DE641777417.description: • defend a given position on an issue, based on their findings (e.g., defend the use of a particular renewable or nonrenewable source of heat energy in a particular application)

8235D121B51A4AD2B61B2A4A90FC8CBD.description: • communicate questions, ideas, intentions, plans and results, using lists, notes in point form, sentences, data tables, graphs, drawings, oral language and other means (e.g., use electronic hardware to generate data summaries and graphs of group data, and present these findings)

40F0B4F447644880B82E2171DA5A3B78.description:
Communication and Teamwork 
Students will: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

9D96E4B964D64555A3962C9732EBACBC.description: • test the design of a constructed device or system (e.g., test a personally-constructed heating or cooling device)

A989CCF880D445A68D8E3941FEB4ACD0.description: • identify and evaluate potential applications of findings (e.g., the application of heat transfer principles to the design of homes and protective clothing)

5CD6991DADEE4A8FBB3216C12C43BBFF.description: • identify, and suggest explanations for, discrepancies in data

D5A475112F034F868268C4AD92835ECD.description:
• compile and display data, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow
charts, tables, bar graphs and line graphs (e.g., construct a database to enter, compare and
present data on the insulative properties of different materials)

02406555ED4B493C954910E5CC4DEB9A.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting 
Students will: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

F4E79DC0EB554CDBA941FEFD53C9020A.description: • carry out procedures, controlling the major variables (e.g., show appropriate attention to controls in investigations of the insulative properties of different materials)

F37DE551C5564134975B530147A72921.description: • use instruments effectively and accurately for collecting data and information (e.g., accurately read temperature scales and use a variety of thermometers; demonstrate skill in downloading text, images, and audio and video files on methods of solar heating)

8B0FF676506F40B9974556064645157F.description: • select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., describe current solar energy applications in Canada, based on information from a variety of print and electronic sources)

A3F4EB3B8BE94DBEAF2806BACD130B80.description: • identify data and information that are relevant to a given problem or issue

87A95FB353544BAC983386A93406B4B3.description:
Performing and Recording 
Students will: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

C31CB87F4B9E4EABB33ECC1D32A00CBF.description: • design an experiment, and control the major variables (e.g., design an experiment to evaluate two alternative designs for solar heating a model house)

F8D3647DC57449FF902A189CF2F61F96.description: • phrase questions in a testable form, and clearly define practical problems (e.g., rephrase a general question, such as: “How can we cut heat loss through windows?” to become “What effect would the addition of a plastic layer have on heat loss through window glass?” or “How would the use of double- or triple-paned windows affect heat loss?”)

524E7A3C10B94E41B0F7773922354027.description: • identify questions to investigate arising from a problem or issue (e.g., ask a question about the source of cold air in a building, or about ways to prevent cold areas)

393A8ACC58494BDEB261F9B4948D7F71.description: • identify science-related issues (e.g., identify an economic issue related to heat loss in a building)

685587ABAD134962B85D0AAB3717C39D.description:
Initiating and Planning 
Students will: Ask questions about the relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

5ABA1FDA147D4C509A775C79C7399E8B.description: • identify positive and negative consequences of energy use, and describe examples of energy conservation in their home or community

24C81D27F2C34790A5493CB4D4735EC4.description: • compare the energy consumption of alternative technologies for heat production and use, and identify related questions and issues (e.g., compare the energy required in alternative cooking technologies, such as electric stoves, gas stoves, microwave ovens and solar cookers; identify issues regarding safety of fuels, hot surfaces and combustion products)

98188E7FDF0C41F6A2F71A8645A2F9CC.description: • identify and evaluate different sources of heat and the environmental impacts of their use (e.g., identify advantages and disadvantages of fossil fuel use; compare the use of renewable and nonrenewable sources in different applications)

BA39F3E24B4D4511ABDAE9BF9A2A6496.description: 4. Analyze issues related to the selection and use of thermal technologies, and explain decisions in terms of advantages and disadvantages for sustainability

E008D715BFBD4D08BB2120FB7275A779.description: • investigate and describe practical problems in controlling and using thermal energy (e.g., heat losses, excess energy consumption, damage to materials caused by uneven heating, risk of fire)

22E073F9F96F4B6FB5C0A1F34A17FCB7.description: • describe and interpret the function of household devices and systems for generating, transferring, controlling or removing thermal energy (e.g., describe in general terms the operation of heaters, furnaces, refrigerators and air conditioning devices)

0050D46C47E649D9917990134B75E312.description: • explain the operation of technological devices and systems that respond to temperature change (e.g., thermometers, bimetallic strips, thermostatically-controlled heating systems)

424DBEED7836468FACA60E685C0DC403.description: • compare and evaluate materials and designs that maximize or minimize heat energy transfer (e.g., design and build a device that minimizes energy transfer, such as an insulated container for hot drinks; evaluate different window coatings for use in a model home)

4DE21B504AAF4ED48CD095B8A5AC5F70.description: • describe examples of passive and active solar heating, and explain the principles that underlie them (e.g., design of homes to maximize use of winter sunshine)

277AE217FEC2461182289B3FCA256D93.description: • describe ways in which thermal energy is produced naturally (e.g., solar radiation, combustion of fuels, living things, geothermal sources and composting)

3E752B8D3613482BB9CB0F6A8B193377.description: 3. Apply an understanding of heat and temperature in interpreting natural phenomena and technological devices

CC61DCC5CDB34583B576B0DC71D8BEC0.description: • investigate and describe the effects of heating and cooling on the volume of different materials, and identify applications of these effects (e.g., use of expansion joints on bridges and railway tracks to accommodate thermal expansion)

0F3287633DEB499DA05FDBB136BFC5E9.description: • distinguish between heat and temperature; and explain temperature, using the concept of kinetic energy and the particle model of matter

6062971689534DD6861276D1A961E067.description: • describe the effect of heat on the motion of particles; and explain changes of state, using the particle model of matter

34BCC3BF7BDF4FC4AB1C1E811393B4CC.description: • compare the absorption of radiant heat by different surfaces) explain how heat is transmitted by conduction, convection and radiation in solids, liquids and gases

64324DAA36054008896DEECAFE9DBBB6.description: • compare heat transmission in different materials (e.g., compare conduction of heat in different solids;

5F2A15BE10F94DACAA83E60430DFD34A.description: 2. Describe the nature of thermal energy and its effects on different forms of matter, using informal observations, experimental evidence and models

858252E4528F42D4911D6189FDB4EFD8.description: • identify examples of personal and societal choices in using energy resources and technology (e.g., identify choices that affect the amount of hot water used in their daily routines; identify choices in how that water is heated)

709807E1E91342D7975730A2EBA47065.description: • identify and explain uses of devices and systems to generate, transfer, control or remove thermal energy (e.g., describe how a furnace and wall thermostat keep a house at a constant temperature)

AD2926B769EF40C08A1B16E23799D73E.description: • trace linkages between human purposes and the development of heat-related materials and technologies (e.g., development of hair dryers and clothes dryers; development of protective clothing, such as oven mitts, ski suits and survival clothing)

AF975A4FA861442CB3A67DE68D4F35E8.description: • investigate and interpret examples of heat-related technologies and energy use in the past (e.g., investigate uses of heat for domestic purposes, such as cooking or home heating, and for industrial processes, such as ceramics, metallurgy or use of engines)

83603759909A4BD0A25D8E97018EB4EB.description: 1. Illustrate and explain how human needs have led to technologies for obtaining and controlling thermal energy and to increased use of energy resources

3FC0A8F27E0F4B7EA1C2CC083A519795.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society

1B2E959509164575A2A3530E640AE1B6.description:
Safety 
Students will be encouraged to: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., read the labels on materials before using them, and ask for help if safety symbols are not clear or understood; clean their work area during and after an activity)

5B4A3E26190049D4A9D084D5D30228FE.description:
Stewardship 
Students will be encouraged to: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a
sustainable environment (e.g., voluntarily care for plants in a school or home environment; assume personal responsibility for their impact on the environment; recognize that their consumption habits have environmental consequences)

407AD30738F0403E820A64806FB11C21.description:
Collaboration 
Students will be encouraged to: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g.,
assume responsibility for their share of work in preparing for investigations and in gathering and recording evidence; consider alternative ideas and approaches suggested by members of the group; share the responsibility for difficulties encountered in an activity)

4AC1D09A6BF148A8BBC2F6E4E10FDC79.description:
Scientific Inquiry 
Students will be encouraged to: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and
issues (e.g., consider the nutrient content of food they eat and the potential presence of residues; consider observations and ideas from a number of sources, during investigations and before drawing conclusions)

2084893D329B4C66B3265733AD0B5BB8.description:
Mutual Respect 
Students will be encouraged to: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., show awareness of the diversity of agricultural practices used by societies around the world at different times through history; appreciate the role of Aboriginal knowledge in identifying useful herbs and medicines)

8507C782B27D40838ED3E16201099B3B.description:
Interest in Science 
Students will be encouraged to: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., observe plants in the local community, and ask questions about plants with unusual characteristics; pursue a hobby related to the study of living things; express an interest in science-related/technology-related careers)

2D28C1F363174CB49952183B5DA2062D.description: • evaluate individual and group processes used in planning, problem solving, decision making and completing a task

1DDD535B216541D186B8A8F85DA3E7CD.description: • communicate questions, ideas, intentions, plans and results, using lists, notes in point form, sentences, data tables, graphs, drawings, oral language and other means (e.g., show the growth of a group of plants over time through a data table and diagrams)

AB42EFCA22A549389D7B19ADBBA96758.description: • receive, understand and act on the ideas of others (e.g., adopt and use an agreed procedure for counting or estimating the population of a group of plants)

3FC4712D66C344D5AC23AC766B6F1C43.description:
Communication and Teamwork 
Students will: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

869AF7220FF24F1586A3889D377B4DCF.description: • identify new questions and problems that arise from what was learned

EA2F01FE399B4336AAE43F550133F0B9.description: • compile and display data, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, bar graphs and line graphs (e.g., prepare a record of a plant’s growth that charts its development in terms of height, leaf development, flowering and seed production)

E5B5C21B99DD4D0E856040CD5818F41C.description: • use and/or construct a classification key (e.g., distinguish among several grain varieties, using a classification guide or key)

3CFC2FC497DD411A98991C9DF168B1EC.description: • identify strengths and weaknesses of different methods of collecting and displaying data (e.g., compare two different ways to measure the amount of moisture in soil; evaluate different ways of presenting data on the health and growth of plants)

7F78CC9A48C547EAAA0F3D9CD938632C.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting 
Students will: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

36959EBC1011452EB7DE7EAABBD0F38A.description: • estimate measurements (e.g., estimate plant populations; estimate the surface area of a leaf)

1387890F943B4117ACF8ED0D16A1180C.description: • observe and record data, and create simple line drawings (e.g., describe plant growth, using qualitative and quantitative observations; draw and describe plant changes resulting from an experimental procedure)

B4F2235256694D129A9B65CC5BAB17D8.description: • construct and test a prototype design to achieve a specific purpose (e.g., develop and test a device for watering house plants over a two-week absence)

627485574CCE4723A11591A53DD8A515.description: • research information relevant to a given problem

D24AF379840349E5949BE6004C225FF9.description:
Performing and Recording 
Students will: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

CE344BF693264EE0BDC798C922ED5F05.description: • formulate operational definitions (e.g., define the health of a plant in terms of its colour and growth pattern)

FA5B72CC9826433A95E904D0CA3689B2.description: • state a prediction and a hypothesis based on background information or an observed pattern of events (e.g., predict the effect of a particular plant treatment)

7D3D0778155E4C9DABBC3BFF11890568.description: • rephrase questions in a testable form, and clearly define practical problems (e.g., rephrase a broad question, such as: “What amount of fertilizer is best?” to become “What effect will the application of different quantities of fertilizer X have on the growth of plant Y and its environment?”)

4BF1D445C2D848148FFD79A45A493DC5.description: • identify questions to investigate arising from practical problems and issues (e.g., What methods will help limit moisture loss from plants and soil? What reduction in the loss of soil moisture can be achieved through the use of a plastic ground sheet or through the use of a plastic canopy?)

0E4EC45AD41A467A80D37CDBE706D5FF.description: • define practical problems (e.g., identify problems in growing plants under dry conditions)

514AB0A765174FFAA5B0B15075E8B47D.description:
Initiating and Planning 
Students will: Ask questions about the relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

E6415197F2A34C0FBB218729D02704BC.description: • identify the effects of different practices on the sustainability of agriculture and environmental resources (e.g., identify positive and negative effects of using chemical fertilizers and pesticides and of using organic farming practices)

5826881B690141319F9E5828EB99C4D1.description: • investigate and identify intended and unintended consequences of environmental management practices (e.g., identify problems arising from monocultural land use in agricultural and forestry practices, such as susceptibility to insect infestation or loss of diversity)

0A0CA3859C0F4533981950ECC9FA5C7A.description: • investigate and describe the development of plant varieties through selective breeding, and identify related needs and problems (e.g., identify needs leading to the development of new grain varieties; identify problems arising from the development of new plant varieties that require extensive fertilization)

B3580C80E60D409AA5D707479D1A0F5A.description: 4. Identify and interpret relationships among human needs, technologies, environments, and the culture and use of living things as sources of food and fibre

CC33CD4906AC4A91A0A5D59ED6FC841D.description: • describe and interpret the consequences of using herbicides, pesticides and biological controls in agriculture and forestry

1D533D3C989E46CA80FE32A99D39E996.description: • identify practices that may enhance or degrade soils in particular applications

A74FD42495E24A2DBA69016F8ED6E29E.description: • investigate and describe characteristics of different soils and their major component (e.g., distinguish among clayey soils, sandy soils and soils rich in organic content; investigate and describe particle sizes, compaction and moisture content of soil samples)

A1E8B879F8124FB7A115C46827FF5657.description: • describe methods used to increase yields, through modifying the environment and by creating artificial environments (e.g., describe processes used in raising bedding plants or in vegetable production through hydroponics)

6D22430543914881AE6AFBC304968CC5.description: 3. Analyze plant environments, and identify impacts of specific factors and controls

5363BE9891804478B994CEF8F4BD3793.description: • describe life cycles of seed plants, and identify example methods used to ensure their germination, growth and reproduction (e.g., describe propagation of plants from seeds and vegetative techniques, such as cuttings; conduct a germination study; describe the use of beehives to support pollination)

F0293E8E765A499B968B8F01ABCC79BD.description: • describe the processes of diffusion, osmosis, conduction of fluids, transpiration, photosynthesis and gas exchange in plants [Note: This item requires a general understanding of the processes; it does not require knowledge of the specific biochemistry of these processes.]

FBC10DECF6214A4B9F0481673C9C941F.description: • investigate and interpret variations in needs of different plants and their tolerance for different growing conditions (e.g., tolerance for drought, soil salinization or short growing seasons)

8CC57E100F874168893D0F2EEF2860D6.description: • investigate and interpret variations in plant structure, and relate these to different ways that plants are adapted to their environment (e.g., distinguish between plants with shallow spreading roots and those with deep taproots; describe and interpret differences in flower form and in the timing of flower production)

9D2D5F1EE8234552AD01BACBEC34448D.description:
• describe the general structure and functions of seed plants (e.g., describe the roots, stem, leaves
and flower of a common local plant)

66621E65CDEF431F81D0253F96C93147.description: 2. Investigate life processes and structures of plants, and interpret related characteristics and needs of plants in a local environment

900B2FD9CF3D4B939430D0AE0C35CE06.description: • investigate practical problems and issues in maintaining productive plants within sustainable environments, and identify questions for further study (e.g., investigate the long-term effects of irrigation practices or fertilizer use)

DBDCDFA4560E4769899EA1C9A9526AD1.description: • investigate trends in land use from natural environments (e.g., forests, grasslands) to managed environments (e.g., farms, gardens, greenhouses) and describe changes

E5FC8B6C669E41E99894D22402FA511D.description: • describe human uses of plants as sources of food and raw materials, and give examples of other uses (e.g., identify uses of plants as herbs or medicines; describe plant products, and identify plant sources on which they depend)

96DC57D15BBE46D2B3231ED665CF3EF2.description: • illustrate and explain the essential role of plants within the environment

8BDAB561885E42F68C41F4705C4FD3DF.description: 1. Investigate plant uses; and identify links among needs, technologies, products and impacts

C3A9B3A82D2E420A8676839DFB464427.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society

54A6AA6D166547AF838AF130B3BAF3B8.description: Unit B: Plants for Food and Fibre

AABCEA7EEC6D49438E5753AF837B5AE8.description:
Safety 
Students will be encouraged to: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., select safe methods and tools for collecting evidence and solving problems; assume personal responsibility for their involvement in a breach of safety or in waste disposal procedures)

70400FB729E148E9A048D652B6997BCE.description:
Stewardship 
Students will be encouraged to: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., assume personal responsibility for their impact on the environment; predict consequences of proposed personal actions on the environment; consider both immediate and long-term consequences of group actions; identify, objectively, potential conflicts between responding to human wants and needs and protecting the environment)

A696334B6F394FB4A89B901750CC432A.description:
Collaboration 
Students will be encouraged to: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., consider alternative ideas, perspectives and approaches suggested by members of the group; share the responsibility for carrying out decisions)

64C1F5BC722540D7A28E6038D6884353.description:
Scientific Inquiry 
Students will be encouraged to: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and
issues (e.g., take the time to accurately gather evidence and use instruments carefully; consider observations, ideas and perspectives from a number of sources during investigations and before drawing conclusions and making decisions)

9823E5B510BB4134988F9A7EA564383D.description:
Mutual Respect 
Students will be encouraged to: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with
different views and backgrounds (e.g., show awareness of and respect for aboriginal perspectives on the link between humans and the environment)

8095349BB42F4CD18E323649D76BA4A6.description:
Interest in Science
Students will be encouraged to: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., take an interest in media reports on environmental issues, and seek out further information; express an interest in conducting scientific investigations of their own design; develop an interest in careers related to environmental sciences)

D04AF23EE8B5487780EF11DA19310140.description: • defend a given position on an issue, based on their findings (e.g., make a case for or against on an issue, such as: “Should a natural gas plant be located near a farming community?”)

AE40961FDD54420C8338DAC0343B8D94.description: • evaluate individual and group processes used in planning, problem solving, decision making and completing a task

F4837982B237488A9F78B3A30D98AC45.description: • communicate questions, ideas, intentions, plans and results, using lists, notes in point form, sentences, data tables, graphs, drawings, oral language and other means (e.g., present findings from an analysis of a local issue, such as the control of the beaver population in a nearby wetland)

B7AA7BB76BDC4C2BA58299DBEDEECE5F.description:
Communication and Teamwork 
Students will: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

047C7CFBECEF4C7381A0E8A66A30DEEC.description: • classify organisms found in a study plot

DD77B8C442884F15B57439919EDE7C51.description: • compile and display data, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, bar graphs and line graphs (e.g., illustrate a food web, based on observations made within a given environment)

13B0CAF7FCCD48F185C38D5D0CF900CF.description: • identify strengths and weaknesses of different methods of collecting and displaying data (e.g., compare two different approaches to measuring the amount of moisture in an environment; analyze information presented by proponents on two sides of an environmental issue)

B9756912929D47A9A7D40DEBD1F30C49.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting 
Students will: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

7BFE7E93E14C456BB2D148700937361D.description: • estimate measurements (e.g., estimate the population of a given plant in a one square metre quadrat, and use this figure to estimate the population within an area of 100 square metres)

636CCCF195CA4B52964BD5069153B689.description: • use tools and apparatus effectively and accurately for collecting data (e.g., measure factors, such as temperature, moisture, light, shelter and potential sources of food, that might affect the survival and distribution of different organisms within a local environment)

019082634DB64C09BF2BD0A990C38A39.description:
• select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of
the same source (e.g., compile information on a global environmental issue from books,
magazines, pamphlets and Internet sites, as well as from conversations with experts)

4DD92F7F49BC44E595E5924FBBA4B534.description: • research information relevant to a given problem or issue

EDBF9AA8C41C437688E82B742590FE77.description:
Performing and Recording 
Students will: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

D2A2BDBDD3C541698F385B1521F75CFA.description: • select appropriate methods and tools for collecting data and information (e.g., select or develop a method for estimating a plant population within a given study plot; design a survey as a first step in investigating an environmental issue)

BADBDD02606C4A038A6EDD07C2DD592C.description: • state a prediction and a hypothesis based on background information or an observed pattern of events (e.g., predict changes in the population of an organism if factor X were increased, or if a species were introduced or removed from the ecosystem; propose factors that will affect the population of a given animal species)

F019237D6A034789BBD8B0A65B8ED07F.description: • identify questions to investigate arising from practical problems and issues (e.g., identify questions, such as: “What effects would an urban or industrial development have on a nearby forest or farming community?”)

5DF453F1205649FDA77A5B1DF9DE2D4B.description: • identify science-related issues (e.g., identify a specific issue regarding human impacts on environments)

A0265089A28342A2AE3C4E31DB2CD2F5.description:
Initiating and Planning 
Students will: Ask questions about the relationships between and among observable variables, and plan
investigations to address those questions

CEE8AA25D73141958A11170A8EF1919B.description: • analyze a local environmental issue or problem based on evidence from a variety of sources, and identify possible actions and consequences (e.g., analyze a local issue on the control of the beaver population in a nearby wetland, and identify possible consequences)

076A6375EB484D7A9C0BAACB34E7FC3A.description: • illustrate, through examples, the limits of scientific and technological knowledge in making decisions about life-supporting environments (e.g., identify limits in scientific knowledge of the impact of changing land use on individual species; describe examples in which aboriginal knowledge—based on long-term observation—provides an alternative source of understanding)

97AC8E3C99BB455186BC740BFA2285DF.description: • describe and interpret examples of scientific investigations that serve to inform environmental decision making

9A72ADA3228B474180F95644FEB9030F.description: • identify intended and unintended consequences of human activities within local and global environments (e.g., changes resulting from habitat loss, pest control or from introduction of new species; changes leading to species extinction)

088F72E37CE246C5ABA650D79B754943.description: 4. Describe the relationships among knowledge, decisions and actions in maintaining life-supporting environments

97A3CE3E19E2477096100CE51DC5DBEA.description: • identify signs of ecological succession in local ecosystems (e.g., emergence of fireweed in recently cut forest areas, replacement of poplar by spruce in maturing forests, reestablishment of native plants on unused farmland)

F60AE724BC9C4460873A89BFBF41E334.description: • investigate and interpret evidence of interaction and change (e.g., population fluctuations, changes in weather, availability of food or introduction of new species into an ecosystem)

BF4E5A2CF41B4BBE86BB204C0964E8D4.description: • investigate a variety of habitats, and describe and interpret distribution patterns of living things found in those habitats (e.g., describe and compare two areas within the school grounds—a relatively undisturbed site and a site that has been affected by heavy use; describe and compare a wetland and a dryland area in a local parkland)

F607B50AFF0A46248B78BC06F7D8C8AA.description: 3. Monitor a local environment, and assess the impacts of environmental factors on the growth, health and reproduction of organisms in that environment

A26CE0C1017A499A8EF099BE04458F9E.description: • identify mechanisms by which pollutants enter and move through the environment, and can become concentrated in some organisms (e.g., acid rain, mercury, PCBs, DDT

0FA4FA87B47D4A32BECD043E8101F192.description: • describe the process of cycling carbon and water through an ecosystem

86B29110083B41279A6D9518452BDA1D.description:
• analyze ecosystems to identify producers, consumers and decomposers; and describe how energy is supplied to and flows through a food web, by: 
− describing and giving examples of energy and nutrient storage in plants and animals 
− describing how matter is recycled in an ecosystem through interactions among plants, animals, fungi, bacteria and other microorganisms 
− interpreting food webs, and predicting the effects of changes to any part of a web

CFF4A22512D745E2B5202CA165F28340.description: • analyze an ecosystem to identify biotic and abiotic components, and describe interactions among these components

F6BFAD6373EA495D85A5F92D057F09B1.description: 2. Trace and interpret the flow of energy and materials within an ecosystem

012B453FE2924F99A701F9654F4237DE.description: • analyze personal and public decisions that involve consideration of environmental impacts, and identify needs for scientific knowledge that can inform those decisions

EB715CFB661D49358CF7ADB81C55CEF7.description:
• identify examples of human impacts on ecosystems, and investigate and analyze the link between these impacts and the human wants and needs that give rise to them 
(e.g., identify impacts of the use of plants and animals as sources of food, fibre and other materials; identify potential impacts of waste products on environments)

ADFB57283701467CAF375B939306E0B2.description: • describe examples of interaction and interdependency within an ecosystem (e.g., identify examples of dependency between species, and describe adaptations involved; identify changing relationships between humans and their environments, over time and in different cultures—as, for example, in aboriginal cultures)

40866802EB3E4B78A15593CCD9D41691.description: • illustrate how life-supporting environments meet the needs of living things for nutrients, energy sources, moisture, suitable habitat, and exchange of gases

DE7EBA76EE774149AC05F80926590390.description:
1. Investigate and describe relationships between humans and their environments, and identify related
issues and scientific questions

1B7E1E67523847998E3600D2A82C99FB.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society
